hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Lubaba ibn al-Mundhir: When Allah forgave Abu Lubaba after his tawbah (repentance), he came to the Prophet ﷺ saying: 'I will indeed abandon the dwelling of my people wherein I committed the sin, and I will sever myself from my wealth as sadaqah for Allah and His Messenger.' The Prophet ﷺ said to him: 'One-third of it suffices for you.'

chainIssues: Muhammad ibn Abi Hafsa is graded as weak (Da'if) by Abu Hatim and others, which compromises the entire chain

Al-Zuhri is known as a mudallis (type 2) though generally reliable, but his use of عَنْ still presents some ambiguity

potential_issues.issue: Weak narrator at the beginning of chain
potential_issues.impact: Muhammad ibn Abi Hafsa is classified as weak by major hadith scholars including Abu Hatim. His presence at the beginning of the transmission chain significantly weakens the hadith's reliability regardless of other narrators' strength

potential_issues.issue: Tadlis by Muhammad ibn Abi Hafsa
potential_issues.impact: Muhammad ibn Abi Hafsa is known for practicing tadlis (concealment of the line of transmission). When using عَنْ without explicit direct hearing (سمعت or حدثنا), this creates uncertainty about the actual nature of transmission

potential_issues.issue: Use of عَنْ from al-Zuhri despite his known tadlis tendency
potential_issues.impact: Though al-Zuhri is generally considered reliable and his tadlis is type 2 (not affecting acceptance), the use of عَنْ combined with the already weak narrator above creates compounded ambiguity

The text mentions variant chains through Sulayman ibn Abd al-Rahman, Abdullah from al-Layth, and Ibn Ishaq, indicating multiple transmission paths for this story, which may suggest different versions or traditions

Topics: Incident of Abu Lubaba's repentance and reconciliation with the Prophet ﷺ

hadiths.english_translation: From Imran ibn Muslim, from Khaythama: I was with Ibn Abbas regarding vows. Muhammad ibn Aqabah said: Ruh ibn Ataa narrated to us, he said: Husayn ibn Imran narrated to us. Imran al-Qattan reported from Husayn, from al-Shibani. Abu Dumra said: Husayn ibn Imran narrated to us, from al-Zuhri, strange narrations (munakir).

narrators.name: Ibn Abbas
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Chain through Imran ibn Muslim and Khaythama has weak links with unknown reliability
Both early narrators are majhul al-hal
The hadith stops at Ibn Abbas (mawquf), making it a companion saying rather than prophetic tradition
Ruh ibn Ataa is known as a weak narrator
Husayn ibn Imran is explicitly noted to have munkar (rejected) narrations from al-Zuhri
Multiple chains through this narrator are marked as unreliable
Abu Dumra's evaluation explicitly states these are 'manakirur' (strange/rejected narrations)

potential_issues.impact: Ruh ibn Ataa and especially Husayn ibn Imran al-Jahni are both classified as weak narrators, with the latter having explicit documentation of munkar (rejected) narrations
Abu Dumra explicitly states that Husayn ibn Imran's narrations from al-Zuhri are 'manakirur' (rejected/strange narrations), indicating a well-known problem with this narrator's reliability
The text explicitly notes 'wala yutabi' fi hadithih' (there is no corroboration in his hadith), indicating this narrator is isolated in his narrations without support from other reliable chains
The various chains through different narrators (Imran al-Qattan, Abu Dumra) all have problems, suggesting systemic weakness in the transmission of this material

Topics: Scholarly evaluation of weak narrator Husayn ibn Imran al-Jahni

hadiths.english_translation: From Karib and Ikrimah. Ali said: I abandoned his hadith. Sharik said: From Husayn, from Ikrimah, from Ibn Abbas, the Prophet ﷺ said about Umm Ibrahim: 'Free her,' but this did not become authentic. Amr said, from Ataa, from Ibn Abbas: Mother slaves are only like your goat or your camel. Abu Abdullah said: This is what is well-known from the fatwa of Ibn Abbas.
